body: @junichi11 Should I squash and merge?
@junichi11 BTW are the "custom" script compulsory now? :thinking:  Or if the field is empty. the default script will be used?

The reported bug is fixed.
I had wrong PHP test file - declaration of `A::returnSelf(): self` can't be overiden with `B::returnSelf(): self`.

@tmysik There were unused imports... sorry.
We can merge since this change should not affect CI. : https://github.com/apache/netbeans/compare/84a3d25fbc3919afb0999c041ae54b284ea5fd0a..23d9fa9ef01a13395448761fe74e0f18eb57ff4e

Let's merge as it is. Maybe, it would be easy to read when someone see the logs.

>  if the field is empty. the default script will be used?

Yes :)

Thank you for the research.

> Having said all that I am in favor of providing the csv/tsv option and additionally the .xlsx option by using **fastexcel**. Old .xls format was coming for free when using POI and code-wise it was pretty similar to .xlsx, so it made sense to export in that too. Now that we are talking about using two different libraries I think we can skip .xls support because the format is too old, the produced files are larger than .xlsx in general and I don't think adding it adds any actual value.

I think useing fastexcel is a sensible approach. If I'm not mistaken the footprint will shrink to ~100kB. (opczip + fastexcel). That sounds good to me.

Edit: One more relevant thing: The license situation with fastexcel is good (both dependencies are ALv2, LGPL is a no-go for ASF projects).
One Question. Why the gradle and libs.gradle ended up in the java cluster?

Regarding gradle - the gradle module depends on "java.platform" from the "java" cluster. Normally java cluster depends on extide, but here is a module from extide depending on a module from java - that is a dependency in the wrong direction. Moving gradle is probably not the only solution, so if you have a better one, great!
Good catch. Thanks. Maybe I should remove the java.platform dependency from the Gradle module instead.

@matthiasblaesing Hi and thanks for your feedback.

I have pushed a few changes. I am using the `fastexcel` lib to produce the .xlsx files and have removed the .xls support all together. The `fastexcel` libraries are indeed less than 100k in size.

I have left some of the Apache poi dependencies which are however used only in the unit tests. I have done that because it was easier to write the tests that way and they shouldn't contribute to the final size of the Netbeans artifact.

Finally, I have added the license related files for the external libraries.

Please, let me know if you have any comment.

@KacerCZ Looks good to me but please verify the test failures, thanks.

@junichi11 Once everything is OK for you, feel free to merge. Thanks.
@junichi11 Looks good to me, just a few comments/questions. Thanks!
Build failure was caused by network connection problem and is not related to content of PR.
Sorry this was a mistake.
@tmysik Thanks a lot for your review and your time!
@junichi11 @tmysik Thanks for review.
Got an approval and a clean CI state before updating the apichanges.xml, merging it now.
Gradle project is now independent from Java Platform.
Thanks Laszlo for doing this! (I apologize for not commenting sooner - too much to do.)

@neilcsmith-net - it would be IMO awesome if we would have a C/C++ support in 12.1, but not sure if any further discussions/reviews are needed.

@jlahoda sounds good to me.  But would like to ensure it's in first beta for testing, so if it's ready then could you merge by Monday?  Maybe a lazy consensus thread on the mailing list to say you plan to do so if you feel needs further discussion/review given limited timescale?

I've just realised (while looking at it for something else) that even if GPL+CPE gets approval we won't be able to merge this as is.  The media module includes GLib and GStreamer code that is licensed under LGPL.  Even if we didn't include that, further checking shows that Webkit is also LGPL.  Shipping without JavaFX-Web seems less useful?!

https://github.com/openjdk/jfx/tree/jfx14/modules/javafx.media/src/main/legal
https://github.com/openjdk/jfx/tree/jfx14/modules/javafx.web/src/main/legal
Is the Travis failure in the GraalVM tests a concern or coincidence?
@junichi11 ready for 12.1?  Have wanted this myself a few times in the past. :+1:
@junichi11 @tmysik Thanks for review.

It will be nice to have more formatting options, for example, like in WebStorm:
![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2444896/87813591-7c8a2580-c862-11ea-9ae0-29ff4da51cd3.PNG)

At least these two are must:
![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2444896/87813991-413c2680-c863-11ea-9723-13212ab4d730.PNG)
Thank you - change looks sane and in my test worked as expected.

> Is the Travis failure in the GraalVM tests a concern or coincidence?

Concern.  Apologies, I've didn't run full tests.

Actually ... it's very interesting. @JaroslavTulach could have more deeper insight in this matter. The failure is actually caused by  **classloader mismatch**. 

`GraalJSTest` - the testcase actually run by `junit` ant task is loaded by AppClassLoader, while hamcrest is being loaded by ModuleSystem$SystemClassLoader. There are two inconsistencies:
- NbModuleSuite only loads `org.junit.**` from AppClassLoader, not `org.hamcrest.**`
- the `lib.junit4` module does not list `org.hamcrest.**` as public packages, although it contains the relevant classes.
@junichi11 Sure, would you like me to update ticket NETBEANS-1646 or create a new one?
@qmegas As a new issue. Thanks!

>     * NbModuleSuite only loads `org.junit.**` from AppClassLoader, not `org.hamcrest.**`

cc43414 seems to be the correct fix.
Thanks Samuel for discovering and fixing the problem.
@junichi11 Done [NETBEANS-4605](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-4605)
@neilcsmith-net I've created a new branch (`php80-support`). We will merge PRs related to PHP8.0 into it. Thanks.
Sváťa has gone for a vacation. @neilcsmith-net if it is OK to merge, feel free to do so. I am convinced the change prepared by Sváťa improves the exception handling quite significantly.

The primary motivation of this PR was to bring modern HTML rendering engine into Apache NetBeans. With the latest finding and current Apache licensing policy, it does not seem possible to include WebKit at all. Closing.
Yes, actually waiting for re-approval after the changes. Sorry, I was out of Internet connection yesterday
@junichi11 sounds good! Note that if the current spec version is 2.72, then the spec version for 12.2 should (by default) be 2.73.  It's only automatically incremented once on merge window opening.
@sdedic go ahead from my perspective. Your choice whether to squash or not first.  Whatever makes sense.
@jlahoda what do you want to do on this one?  Still requiring changes?
Should we merge this now?

@juneau001 what's the status on this?  Looking back through older PRs, and noticed this neither merged or had a milestone attached.  If ready, would be useful if you could squash commits as makes sense, and force push your branch if possible.
What's status on this one?  Merging, fixing, closing?

@neilcsmith-net I would love to get this PR pushed!  I've had a check failing and I am not sure what to do with it...seems to be Windows related?  I can try to perform the squash commit and force push if you think this CI build check failure is safe to move past for now.

What check?  Check failing on Travis?  Retriggered the one failure I could see there, although not Windows related?!

Would like to get this in to master in next 24hrs for first beta if we're going to try and include in 12.1.

I'm also unable to manually confirm if new patch works or not as my IDE gets to some weird state where it highlights records even I rollback the original patch.

This is probably the best patch I can offer until NetBeans will be testable on JDK 14.

@neilcsmith-net Yes that failing Travis check seemed to indicate a Windows build failure when I tried to investigate.  I'll look into it again once it completes the process and I will try to move this in 24 hours.  I appreciate you pinging me on this PR.  It would be great to have this in 12.1.
@tmysik We need not hurry because we can't merge PRs into the master branch now :)
@neilcsmith-net I performed a git rebase -i master on the jakartaee8_support branch.  Seemed to squash all commits in the branch.  Please let me know if this does the trick...thanks!

@juneau001 thanks.  It's still showing 7 commits here.  I think you need to then rebase on top of `HEAD~6` or `HEAD~7`.  See the page at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/git%3A+squash+and+merge (but without the merge to master).  If need be I can do that, but possibly better if you can check everything is correct.
Sorry, but it seems quite a few test jobs are failing - could you please investigate? Thanks!
Sorry, but the builds say there is some problem with the patch - could you please investigate? Thanks!

@neilcsmith-net I apologize, but when I try to perform a git log --pretty="%h%x09%ae%x09%s" -n 20, then I only see 3 of my commits at the top, followed by many commits from others.  I tried to perform a rebase on top of HEAD~3 and it opened up the selector for all 176 commits from others and attempts to rebase all.  Again, my apologies but this seems to be more complex possibly because I pushed the PR a few times since March and in the meantime synched my environment to the base to keep current and test.  Anything else I can do to get this PR pushed without possibly hurting things?  Thanks for your time and guidance.
@juneau001 no worries, I'll see what I can do.

@juneau001 I've force pushed to your branch so you can double-check before I merge to master.  Did a second checkout and diff and it seems identical.  Think you'd possibly rebased on master without fetching it from upstream?  Seemed slightly out of date - had to resolve a spec version conflict.

@neilcsmith-net Thanks Neil!  I took a look and everything looks correct.  I typically fetch from upstream before I do any work, so I don't believe I rebased on master without fetching.  The issues must have been introduced when I pushed the PR in March, then didn't pick up work again on the PR until summer, where I fetched from master and then made more changes to the branch and re-pushed.
@juneau001 no problem, but something was awry with history relative to master.  Just need to fix this failing test.  Not sure what the fix is meant to be though.

@neilcsmith-net Thanks for your assistance with this PR, it is very much appreciated.  I have loaded this PR via git fetch origin pull/2023/head and built it successfully within my environment.  I am unable to find the cause of the Travis build issues, as it is indicating MacOS build failure.  Let me know if you have any thoughts on how to proceed.

@juneau001 no problem.  The MacOS is GitHub Actions not Travis, and I keep seeing the odd failure with that.  Travis error was something that was green before and again seems to be something that has odd failures.  Going to merge and we can deal with any actual test failure (which I don't think we do have) after beta1. Thanks!

Is the module-source-path part likely to make 12.1 or more realistically 12.2?
@neilcsmith-net This is related to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2184. So I would like to apply this change to `12.1` if possible.
Thank you for your review. OK.

Well, it seems module-source-path has not handled by the IDE at all. I have a "hack" in mind, that would add the module name to the classpath whenever the module-source-path command line arg is used. If that would be enough to make OpenJFX right, then it can happen in 12.1. If we need to really parse the argument and feed back to the IDE then it would take more time.

@lkishalmi Works like a charm, thanks!
Would it make sense to apply this for platform based applications too?
Well this change is on the platform launcher, so from 12.1 it does work on platform based apps as well.

My bad, was looking in the wrong place.
I see it now, but only for ant based applications.
